NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It was carried out by a gang who spent months tunnelling from the sewers in Nice into a bank vault in 1976. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Jacques Cassandri, now 74, published his account eight years ago, when he could no longer be tried for robbery. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But he is being prosecuted for money-laundering - for which there is no statute of limitations in France. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The robbery at the Société Générale branch in Nice on the French Riviera has inspired several books and a major film. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright AFP Image caption The 1976 robbery is the stuff of legend in France NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The gang used rubber rafts in the sewers, installing hundreds of metres of electrical cables for lighting, to reach the place where they dug an 8m (26ft) tunnel to the bank's basement. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They broke into the vault during a weekend, went through almost 200 safety boxes and made off with 46 million francs - the equivalent of 29 million euros ($36m; £26m). He escaped in 1977, as he was about to be tried, and died in exile 12 years later. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR While on the run, Spaggiari wrote a book confirming police claims that he was the mastermind. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But in 2010 when Mr Cassandri published his book under a pen name, investigators concluded that the author was in fact the leader of the gang. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR They quickly identified Mr Cassandri - a well-known gangster in Marseille. He admitted to police that he took part in the robbery but has denied the money-laundering charges. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This book is a novel, and a novel is not a piece of evidence," a defence lawyer told AFP news agency.
